post2_intro: Here are some ways to make your React application faster, smarter, and adhere to the best current practices.
functionalVsClass_intro: Functional components in React allow for a more modern approach to building components by using hooks for state and effects, which can lead to less verbose and clearer code.

functionalVsClass_class.title: Class Components
functionalVsClass_class.description: Traditionally, class components were the only option in React for managing state and lifecycle events, which could become bulky due to the need for explicit lifecycle methods like componentDidMount, componentDidUpdate, componentWillUnmount, etc.

functionalVsClass_functional.title: Functional Components with Hooks
functionalVsClass_functional.description: Introduced in React 16.8, hooks allow functional components to manage state and side effects, making the code less verbose and more clear.

reactMemo_usage.title: Using React.memo
reactMemo_usage.description: React.memo is a higher-order component that memorizes the output of a functional component. This means React will skip rendering the component if its props have not changed between renders, which is useful for avoiding unnecessary renders and enhancing performance.

memo_practical_use.description: React.memo is particularly useful in scenarios where a component has a high rendering cost, receives complex but rarely changing props, or is frequently re-rendered due to changes in the parent component that do not directly affect its props.
memo_practical_use.inefficiency_consequences: A heavy component that re-renders unnecessarily can cause lag or jank in the UI, especially noticeable on low-power devices or with large component trees.

post2_conclusion: By optimizing components with React.memo and preferring functional components over class components, not only do you improve rendering efficiency but also code readability and maintainability. This is crucial for large-scale projects where efficient state management and rendering can significantly impact performance and user experience.
renderOptimization_goal: Ensure that components only re-render when necessary, thereby improving application efficiency.
inefficientRendering_problem: In React, a component re-renders every time its state or props change, but also when the parent component re-renders, regardless of whether the props it receives have changed.
inefficientRendering_description: In this example, ChildComponent will re-render every time the state in ParentComponent is updated, even if the changes are only related to 'count' and do not affect the props ChildComponent receives. This causes unnecessary re-renders of ChildComponent.
efficientRendering_title: Efficiency: Using React.memo, useMemo, and useCallback
efficientRendering_solution: Use React.memo to memorize the component and prevent unnecessary re-renders. Additionally, useMemo and useCallback can be used to avoid unnecessary recreation of values and functions on each render.
efficientRendering_description: In this enhanced example, ChildComponent only re-renders if the 'data' prop changes, thanks to React.memo. Furthermore, useCallback prevents the creation of a new function on each render, and useMemo ensures that 'computeExpensiveValue' is only recalculated when 'text' changes, thus reducing unnecessary workload in render cycles.
stateManagement_goal: Managing state efficiently is crucial for maintaining the performance and readability of React applications. Manage local state only when necessary and avoid elevating state without justification.
stateInefficiency_problem: Developers often elevate state more than necessary or use complex state management solutions when they are not needed, which can lead to excessive prop propagation and unnecessary re-renders.
stateInefficiency_description: Here, ChildComponent only needs to know the state of 'clicked', but 'inputValue' is also managed at the same level, which may not be necessary and causes the ParentComponent to re-render also due to irrelevant changes for ChildComponent.
stateEfficiency_solution: Use local state within components that really need it and consider using Context API or Redux for global states, but always minimizing updates that do not affect the UI.
stateEfficiency_description: In this improved design, ChildComponent manages its own 'clicked' state, freeing ParentComponent from unnecessary responsibility and preventing unnecessary re-renders when 'inputValue' changes.
contextAPI_usage: Context API: Useful for states that are needed across many parts of the component tree but do not change frequently.
reduxMobx_advice: Redux/MobX: These libraries are powerful for managing complex and derived states in large applications, but they introduce additional complexity and possible inefficiencies if not used properly. Use well-designed and memorized selectors to extract state data and reduce re-renders.
stateManagement_conclusion: Managing state efficiently is key to optimizing both the performance and maintainability of React applications, avoiding unnecessary overhead and enhancing the user experience.
lazyLoading_intro: Lazy Loading and Code Splitting are essential techniques in modern React application development to optimize loading and performance. These techniques not only improve initial load speed but also efficiently manage resource utilization by loading only the necessary components or modules when needed.
lazyLoading_definition: Lazy Loading is an optimization technique that involves loading components or resources only when needed, for example, when a user accesses a specific part of the application. This reduces initial load time and memory usage, as not all components load at the same time.
codeSplitting_definition: Code Splitting is the process of dividing an application's code into multiple bundles that can be dynamically loaded at runtime. React supports this technique natively through React.lazy() and Suspense, allowing you to define components that will load only when they are rendered.
inefficientExample_title: Example of Inefficiency Without Lazy Loading and Code Splitting
inefficientExample_description: Suppose you have a large application with several heavy components that are loaded in the main bundle, although only one of them is initially displayed to the user. This could significantly increase initial load time and negatively affect the user experience.
efficientExample_title: Example of Efficient Use of Lazy Loading with React.lazy and Suspense
efficientExample_description: React.lazy() allows you to define a component that will dynamically load only when needed. To handle the component's loading, use Suspense, which allows you to specify a fallback content (such as a loading indicator) while the component is being loaded.
bestPractices_details: Analyze and measure: Use tools like Webpack Bundle Analyzer to identify which components or libraries are inflating your bundle. Dynamic route loading: In multi-route applications, use React.lazy to load route components only when the user navigates to them. Heavy components: Prioritize the use of Lazy Loading for resource-intensive components that are not necessary for the initial load.
performanceImpact_description: Properly implementing Lazy Loading and Code Splitting can significantly improve the performance of your React applications, making pages faster and more responsive, and enhancing the user experience, especially on devices with limited resources or slow connections.
fragmentsUsage_title: 5.- Using Fragments to Reduce the DOM
fragmentsConcept_description: React.Fragment is a feature provided by React that allows developers to group a list of children without adding extra nodes to the DOM tree. This feature is particularly useful when you want to return multiple elements from a component without creating an additional wrapper element in the DOM, such as a <div>.
fragmentsImportance_description: In React, each component must return a single parent element. However, this restriction can lead to an unnecessary abundance of elements in the DOM, such as <div> or <span>, which are used only to satisfy this restriction. This can affect performance, especially in large applications, by increasing the size of the DOM and slowing down DOM manipulations.
fragmentsFunctionality_description: React.Fragment or its shorthand syntax <>...</> allows wrapping multiple elements without adding an extra node to the DOM. This is useful for components that need to return multiple elements at the root level.
exampleWithoutFragments_implication: In this example, the <div> is unnecessary and could even be problematic if this fragment is used within a <table>, as <div> is not a valid descendant within tables according to HTML specification.
exampleWithFragments_implication: Here, React.Fragment allows the <tr> elements to be added directly to the DOM tree of their container without adding an extra <div> node, maintaining the validity of the HTML and avoiding rendering problems.
fragmentsBenefits_details: Lower DOM Load: Fewer elements in the DOM mean a reduced load for rendering and updating the DOM, which is beneficial for performance, especially in complex interfaces. Maintenance of Semantically Correct HTML: Helps maintain the document structure consistent with HTML rules, avoiding rendering errors caused by incorrect nesting of elements.
fragmentsConsiderations_details: Debugging: One possible downside of using React.Fragment is that the elements it groups do not appear as nodes in browser development tools, which can make debugging a bit more complicated. Keys in Fragments: If you are mapping a list of components using React.Fragment, you will need to use <React.Fragment key={keyValue}> to assign keys. Short fragments <>...</> do not support keys, which can be limiting in certain use cases.
fragmentsSummary_description: In summary, React.Fragment is a powerful tool for React developers looking to optimize their applications by reducing the number of unnecessary elements in the DOM, which translates into performance improvements and maintaining clean and semantically correct code.
keysConcept_description: Keys are special attributes you must provide to elements in a list to give each one a stable identity. React uses keys to identify elements that have changed, been added, or removed between re-renders. Providing an appropriate key is crucial for optimizing performance and avoiding issues with component state.
keysImportance_description: When rendering lists in React, using a key that is a unique identifier for each element helps React perform less work during updates. An effective key should be unique among all sibling elements and stable across re-renders.
indicesIssues_title: Problems with Using Indices as Keys
indicesIssues_description: Using array indices as keys is a common practice but can be problematic, especially if the order of elements can change. If keys are array indices and elements shift position, React might not re-render the elements correctly, leading to unexpected behavior, visual bugs, and poor performance due to unnecessary re-renders and incorrect state updates.
inefficientKeysExample_implication: In this scenario, if the elements move, React may not update the DOM correctly, leading to errors in data display.
efficientKeysExample_benefits: By using 'task.id' as the key, each element maintains its identity across re-renders, allowing React to optimize DOM updates.
keysBestPractices_details: Always use a unique identifier from your data as a key. Ensure that keys do not change across re-renders unless the content of the element has changed. Avoid using indices as keys if the order of elements can change.
keysSummary_description: Proper use of keys in React is essential for optimizing the rendering of lists. Choosing keys correctly aids React in efficient DOM management, enhancing performance and reducing the likelihood of errors.
profilerConcept_title: Understanding the Profiler in React Developer Tools
profilerConcept_description: The Profiler is a feature of React Developer Tools that measures the performance of React components during their mounting, updating, and unmounting phases. This tool helps identify performance bottlenecks by showing how long each component takes to render.
profilerImportance_description: Identifying components that take the most time to render can guide developers in specifically optimizing those components, whether by refining their rendering methods, avoiding unnecessary renders, or restructuring parts of the application to enhance overall efficiency.
profilerExample_description: Suppose you have a complex application and notice some user interactions are slow. You can open React Developer Tools, go to the 'Profiler' tab, and record a session while interacting with the application. The profiler will show a breakdown of the rendering time for each component, highlighting areas for potential optimization.
lighthouseConcept_description: Lighthouse is an open-source automated tool designed to improve the quality of web pages. You can use Lighthouse to audit performance, accessibility, best practices, and SEO of your web pages.
lighthouseImportance_title: Importance of Lighthouse and Similar Tools
lighthouseImportance_description: These tools provide a detailed assessment of various aspects of your website, offering key metrics such as First Paint and Time to Interactive. Understanding these metrics and how your code affects each can lead to significant improvements in site performance.
lighthouseExample_description: To use Lighthouse in Google Chrome: Open Chrome DevTools, go to the 'Lighthouse' tab, configure the categories you want to audit, and click 'Generate report'. Lighthouse will perform a series of audits and provide you with a detailed report with optimization recommendations.
devToolsBestPractices_description: Regularly perform performance audits, especially after adding new features to your application. Use the data from these tools to prioritize performance improvements. For example, if Lighthouse indicates a long Time to Interactive, consider techniques like lazy loading, code splitting, or optimizing heavy resources.

imageOptimizationImportance.title: 8.- Importance of Image Optimization
content: Images are often the largest files on most websites. Optimizing them can significantly reduce load times, enhance user interaction, and lower bandwidth costs for both the user and the server.
Key points include:
Load Speed: Optimized images load faster, contributing to a better user experience and enhanced performance on website speed tests such as Google PageSpeed Insights.
Improved SEO: Search engines favor websites that load quickly, meaning that image optimization can positively influence search rankings.
Bandwidth Usage: Fewer data to download means that users with slow or limited connections will have a better browsing experience.

imageOptimizationToolsTechniques.title: Tools and Techniques for Image Optimization
content: Image Compression:
Lossy Compression: Significantly reduces file size by removing some image information. Popular tools include JPEGmini and TinyJPG.
Lossless Compression: Reduces file size without losing visual quality. Tools like OptiPNG and ImageOptim are widely used.
Using Modern Formats:
WebP: Offers superior compression in both lossy and lossless modes. WebP supports transparency (alpha) and animation, making it suitable for various applications on the modern web.
SVG: Ideal for vector graphics such as logos and icons. SVGs are scalable without losing quality, making them perfect for responsive interfaces.

automationWithNodejs.title: Automation with Node.js Tools
automationWithNodejs.description: Sharp is a high-performance library for processing images in Node.js. It allows for resizing, optimizing, and converting images into different formats quickly.

realWorldExamples.title: Real World Examples and Use Cases
content: Optimization during Site Build:
In projects using build systems like Webpack or Gulp, you can configure plugins or tasks that automatically process and optimize all images as part of the build process.
Implement lazy loading for images that are not initially in the user's view. This can be done with native HTML attributes like loading="lazy", or with JavaScript libraries that load images as needed.
Responsive Images:
Use the srcset attribute in the element to provide different versions of an image for different screen resolutions, allowing the browser to choose the optimal image to load.

conclusion.title: Conclusion
content: Image and static resource optimization is not just a minor enhancement task; it is a fundamental part of web development that directly impacts site performance and accessibility. Employing the right tools and techniques can result in significant improvements in load speed, SEO performance, and user satisfaction.

http2ModernServers.title: 9.- HTTP/2 and Modern Servers
http2ModernServers.introduction: The HTTP/2 protocol introduces several significant improvements over HTTP/1.1 that can positively impact your website's load speed and the overall efficiency of communication between the client and the server. Here I provide a detailed description and examples that show the impact of using HTTP/2 versus not using it.

mainFeatures.title: Main Features of HTTP/2
mainFeatures.multiplexing: HTTP/2 allows multiple resource requests to be sent over a single TCP connection. This eliminates the 'head-of-line blocking' problem typical of HTTP/1.1, where subsequent requests must wait for previous ones to complete.
mainFeatures.headerCompression: HTTP/2 reduces the overhead of HTTP headers using HPACK encoding, which compresses repetitive headers in requests.
mainFeatures.resourcePrioritization: Clients can indicate the priority of resources, which helps the server decide the order of responses, optimizing the perceived performance of the site.
mainFeatures.serverPush: The server can send resources it anticipates the client will need without the client explicitly requesting them, which can further reduce page load time.

httpHeadersCacheConfiguration.title: Configuration of HTTP Headers for Cache
httpHeadersCacheConfiguration.introduction: Proper configuration of HTTP headers for browser cache is crucial to leverage the browser's ability to locally store resources. The right cache headers reduce the need to download the same resources on repeated visits, thus reducing latency and data consumption.
httpHeadersCacheConfiguration.cacheControl: This header specifies the cache directives for resources sent from the server. For example, 'Cache-Control: max-age=31536000' indicates that the resource can be stored in the cache for one year.
httpHeadersCacheConfiguration.etag: A unique identifier generated by the server for each version of a resource. It allows the browser to check if the resource has changed since the last download.

impactExamples.title: Examples of the Impact of HTTP/2

withHttp2.multiplexing: A website with many resources (CSS, JavaScript, images) can load them all through a single connection, meaning the page can be rendered more quickly as it doesn't have to establish multiple TCP connections.
withHttp2.headerCompression: In an environment where the same client makes multiple requests (such as in a Single Page Application), reducing the size of headers can significantly decrease the amount of data transmitted.

withoutHttp2.multipleConnections: If not using HTTP/2, each resource requires its own TCP connection or queues behind others in the same connection, which can increase the total page load time due to connection establishment latency.
withoutHttp2.largeRepeatedHeaders: Without the header compression of HTTP/2, each request carries the full weight of the HTTP headers, increasing the amount of data sent over the network.

practicalExample.title: Practical Example of Cache Headers
practicalExample.description: Suppose you have a logo image that rarely changes. You can configure the headers as follows:
practicalExample.code:
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: image/png
Cache-Control: public, max-age=31536000
ETag: 'abcd1234'
practicalExample.outcome: On subsequent visits, the browser will check the cache and can avoid downloading the image again if the ETag has not changed, or if the period specified by max-age has not yet expired.

http2ModernServers.conclusion: Adopting HTTP/2 and properly configuring HTTP headers can have a significant impact on the efficiency and speed of your website, improving both the user experience and SEO performance.

post2_end: Implementing optimization strategies in React not only improves the end-user experience but also ensures that your application is efficient and sustainable over the long term. By adopting optimization techniques such as lazy loading, efficient state management, and rendering optimization, you can significantly reduce load times, decrease resource usage, and enhance scalability. Always remember to measure the impact of these optimizations with appropriate tools to ensure that you are truly enhancing performance without compromising functionality.
title: A Journey of Discovery and Transformation
subtitle: Exploring the Road Less Traveled: My Journey from Physical Labor to Programming
intro: In my life, I have touched on various labor sectors; I've been from the depths of Mexican mines, to selling solar energy on the streets of Dallas, Texas. I was another trader in the club 90, and also an organic machine logging thousands of serial numbers per day of airplane parts by hand in a warehouse in England. I always knew I wasn't at home.
challenges: I always had big questions and few answers, I knew I had made mistakes, I knew I was on a different path, I knew it was "too late" to start something so deep and extensive.
last_chance: Having the mindset, but having to climb thousands and thousands of steps to get the hammer, something that seemed like the last chance. For me, that was learning to program, the discontent with the decisions I made when I did not recognize the supposed value of human time.
physical_mental_limits: Without the mind in its prime, without the strength to climb so high, much less at a pace that had to be accelerated.
motivation: Where did my motivation come from? It's a question equivalent to where did matter come from. The universe and its behavior not understood by man, gives us the answer. Reality is mental, the power of thought moves the fractals of all universes, a place where energy is infinite in its infinities.
philosophy: Where order is in disorder and the command of thought materializes reality, it is so similar to programming, they are the same fundamentals, it is the structure of thought, the logical within the illogical.
blogPostSubtitle: A short story about what keeps me motivated
introParagraph: I started from zero, without having pursued a degree in programming; I had never seen a line of code. Perhaps in my childhood, thanks to a friend who made scripts to bot in a game called Tibia, was my only contact with scripts and automation, but I had never been in contact with a terminal.
challengeParagraph: Without knowing anything, I decided to start satisfying my curiosity. Some of my programmer friends told me it was too late, others told me I needed to complete a full degree, and yet others said I could easily surpass myself alone. So, I started with the basics. I looked for boot camps, but none convinced me; they seemed more like a scam where, if I managed to find a job, I would be sentencing myself to give them a portion of my salaries for the rest of my life. Also, the learning programs seemed convoluted and, beyond simple, extensive, boring, and complicated.
technologyDiscovery: I was aware that it would not be easy, but I started to investigate the most used technologies: CSS, JS, HTML, the triforce of web development. Later, I encountered Node.js, compilation environments, and from question to question, from why to why, I dug a well of questions and answers deeper each day.
codingStart: When I had a notion of certain tools, I began to write pseudocode on my own to try solving typical algorithm problems for interviews, but I had no idea what I was getting into.
codingChallenges: Soon I was solving problems using JavaScript without having the slightest command of the language, not really knowing where it came from or who compiled the language. Questions about the various levels of abstraction arose and answers were lacking when I touched certain strata of knowledge, but at least some doubts were satisfied.
udemyExperience: Later on, a friend gave me his Udemy account (I had neither job nor money at that time in my life, I was completely broke) and I began to solve the courses, first about Node execution environments. That's where I learned a bit about the principles of SOLID and architecture. When I felt more comfortable with certain tasks that I had replicated exactly as in the videos, I began to try creating my own user interfaces. CSS is complicated and tedious when you do not have well-structured ideas of how it works and what solutions it offers, or rather it is impossible to know how something works if you do not even know how to identify a problem due to lack of experience.
learningHTMLCSS: On the go, I learned HTML and CSS, but later had to learn to implement JavaScript, which I was somewhat afraid of because it was my great weakness. At that time, I had been programming in CSS and HTML for 6 months with a few fundamentals of JS, but I had to do it. I started creating simple components, imitating and understanding half of what those from Tailwind did. For this, I was using Figma, but when I had to give them functionality, that's when I had problems. I replicated almost all the components of Tailwind, from counters to presentation cards, but only up to there; I still did not have the macros to understand their implementation in larger projects and that was another great challenge.
designLearning: I started creating prototype websites that looked like haunted houses. I was aware of the design system, but I did not know the macros to be able to implement them with technologies such as CSS modules or Tailwind itself and had no experience in design. In addition to breaking my head with programming, I extensively researched the fundamentals of design, the history of design, the changes that have occurred and how they have emerged thanks to the technologies that the community has been implementing over time.
projectFailures: I failed in several personal projects, but I knew that watching videos and courses I would not learn at the speed I should. My failure and frustration at seeing errors after errors were what made me learn to investigate. I was also between a rock and a hard place due to my financial and personal situation; my situation at those moments gave me no motivation, it seemed the worst decision I had ever made. But I never give up, I fight for what I really want, and my pride is humble, but tough as the rock my father always taught me to be.
firstWebApp: At 9 months, I was already creating my first web application, currently deployed and belonging to a Mexican solar energy company. It had its database implemented, its APIs, REST, CRUD, protocols, providers, and much more. They were 16-hour days for several months of learning on my own, without certifications or courses or classes or absolutely any support except for a single friend who guided me among the fundamentals.
reflectionOnJourney: Today, in October 2024, it has been about 14 months since I started in this world and with what little I have created I feel that I have come too far. This is thanks to trying too hard, because no matter how much back pain my plastic chair caused me, I never gave up. I always knew there were people in the world who would have wanted to be in my place and all the little sacrifice I made was in the name of what they would have done too.

variables.description: Variables are containers for storing data. 'var' is function-scoped, while 'let' and 'const' are block-scoped. 'const' also prevents re-assignment.
variables.example: let x = 10; const y = 5; var z = 15;

dataTypes.description: JavaScript supports several data types. It is dynamically typed, which means the type is determined at runtime.

types.string: A sequence of characters for text, like 'Hello world'.
types.bigInt: For very large integers that Number cannot represent.
types.undefined: A variable declared but not assigned.
types.symbol: A unique value not equal to any other value.

examples.objects: Collections of properties, such as functions, arrays, and dates. Example: const person = { name: 'John', age: 30 };

operators.description: Operators allow performing operations on variables and values.

controlStructures.description: Control structures direct the execution flow.
controlStructures.example: if (x > y) { console.log('x is greater'); } for (let i = 0; i < 5; i++) { console.log(i); }

functionDeclarations.description: Declare a block of code to be executed when called.

functionExpressions.description: Functions can be assigned to variables.
functionExpressions.example: const square = function(x) { return x * x; };

arrowFunctions.description: Shorter syntax, does not bind its own 'this'.

features.letAndConst: let has block scope; const also prevents reassignment.

spread.description: Expands elements where multiple elements are expected.

rest.description: Combines multiple arguments into an array.
rest.example: function sum(...numbers) { return numbers.reduce((total, num) => total + num); }

destructuring.description: Unpacks properties from objects or arrays.
destructuring.example: const { name, age } = person; const [first, second] = [1, 2, 3];

nullishCoalescingOperator.description: This operator is useful for assigning default values to variables that may be null or undefined. It differs from the OR operator (||) in that it only acts on null or undefined and not on other falsy values like 0 or an empty string ('').

optionalChainingOperator.description: Allows reading the value of a deeply nested property in an object chain without having to explicitly validate that each reference in the chain is valid.

withoutOptionalChaining.code: const age = user && user.profile && user.profile.details && user.profile.details.age;

singletonPattern.description: This pattern ensures that a class has only one instance and provides a global access point to it.

factoryPattern.description: Defines an interface for creating an object but allows subclasses to decide which class to instantiate. The Factory Method lets a class delegate instantiation to subclasses.

observerPattern.description: Defines a one-to-many dependency between objects so that when one object changes its state, all its dependents are notified and updated automatically.

tryCatch.description: Provides a way to handle errors without completely stopping the execution of the program. It is useful for catching runtime errors.

promiseErrorHandling.description: Promises have .then() and .catch() methods to handle successful results and errors, respectively.

asyncAwaitErrorHandling.description: async and await simplify working with promises and make code more readable. You can also use try-catch to handle errors in asynchronous functions.

javascriptCuriosities.title: JavaScript Curiosities

historyOfJavaScript.title: History of JavaScript
historyOfJavaScript.description: JavaScript was created in 1995 by Brendan Eich while working at Netscape Communications Corporation. It was originally designed to make web pages more dynamic. The language was developed in just ten days and was initially called 'Mocha', then renamed to 'LiveScript', and finally to 'JavaScript', reflecting a marketing strategy to leverage the popularity of Java at the time. Despite its name, JavaScript is not directly related to Java.
historyOfJavaScript.evolution: Over time, JavaScript has become the backbone of the World Wide Web and has evolved significantly with the introduction of ECMAScript (ES), the technical standard for the language. ECMAScript has seen several versions, each adding more features and improvements, from ES3 in 1999 to ES6 (ECMAScript 2015), which introduced classes, modules, promises, and many other modern capabilities.

typeCoercion.title: Type Coercion
typeCoercion.description: JavaScript is known for its type coercion, where the language automatically converts value types from one form to another. This feature can lead to unexpected and often confusing results.

hoisting.title: Hoisting
hoisting.description: In JavaScript, variable and function declarations are 'hoisted' to the top of their execution context before the code is executed. This can lead to behavior that confuses developers, especially those new to the language.

eventLoopAndSingleThreadedNature.title: Event Loop and Single-Threaded Nature
eventLoopAndSingleThreadedNature.description: Despite being single-threaded, JavaScript can perform non-blocking operations through its event loop model. This model allows JavaScript to handle heavy tasks like I/O without freezing the user interface by managing operations asynchronously.

y2kBug.title: The Y2K Bug
y2kBug.description: Although not specific to JavaScript, the Y2K bug was a famous issue that also affected programs written in JavaScript. The problem arose because many programs represented the year using only the last two digits, which led to confusion when the year changed from 1999 to 2000.

arraySortQuirk.title: Array Sort Quirk
arraySortQuirk.description: JavaScript has some quirks in its built-in functions, such as the sort() method for arrays, which converts elements to strings before comparing them. This can lead to unexpected sorting results.

javascriptCuriosities.conclusion: These examples highlight some of the peculiarities and unique aspects of JavaScript that developers need to be aware of. From its origins to its current state, JavaScript has proven to be a dynamic and essential programming language in modern web application development.

javascriptBestPractices.title: JavaScript Best Practices

cleanAndMaintainableCode.title: Clean and Maintainable Code
cleanAndMaintainableCode.description: Writing well-organized and structured code not only makes it easier to read and maintain but also improves quality and reduces the likelihood of errors.

codeOrganization.title: Code Organization
codeOrganization.description: Use modules or components to separate logic and keep the code organized. Functions should be small and handle only one responsibility. Instead of having one function that does everything, break tasks into smaller functions.

example.badExample: function handleUserData() { /* gets data */ /* validates data */ /* saves data */ }
example.goodExample: function getUserData() { /* gets data */ } function validateUserData(data) { /* validates data */ } function saveUserData(validData) { /* saves data */ }

consistentNaming.title: Consistent Naming
consistentNaming.description: Use descriptive names for variables and functions that clarify their purpose without needing additional comments.

performance.title: Performance Optimization
performance.description: Optimization techniques can significantly improve the speed and efficiency of JavaScript code, especially in large and complex applications.

loopOptimization.title: Loop Optimization
loopOptimization.description: Loops can be a significant source of inefficiency if not handled properly. Reducing the work done inside loops and avoiding excessive use of costly methods within them can improve performance.

example.badExample: for (let i = 0; i < myArray.length; i++) { const item = myArray[i]; console.log(item.name); }
example.goodExample: const length = myArray.length; for (let i = 0; i < length; i++) { console.log(myArray[i].name); }

efficientMemoryManagement.title: Efficient Memory Management
efficientMemoryManagement.description: Avoid memory leaks by keeping control over references and cleaning up event listeners when they are no longer needed.

example.code: function setup() { const button = document.getElementById('saveButton'); button.addEventListener('click', onSave); return function cleanup() { button.removeEventListener('click', onSave); }; }

security.title: JavaScript Security
security.description: JavaScript security is crucial for protecting user data and preventing malicious attacks.

preventingXSS.title: Preventing XSS Attacks
preventingXSS.description: Sanitize and escape any user input that will be rendered in HTML to prevent the execution of malicious scripts.

example.goodExample: const safeInput = escapeHtml(userInput); document.getElementById('output').innerHTML = safeInput; function escapeHtml(str) { return str.replace(/[&<>"']/g, function(match) { return ({ '&': '&', '<': '<', '>': '>', '"': '"', "'": ''' })[match]; }); }

contentSecurityPolicy.title: Content Security Policy (CSP)
contentSecurityPolicy.description: Use Content Security Policy (CSP) to restrict content sources and protect against attacks such as XSS.

javascriptBestPractices.conclusion: Implementing these best practices not only improves code quality but also ensures that applications are more robust, secure, and easy to maintain, which is essential for professional software development.

librariesAndFrameworks.title: Libraries and Frameworks
librariesAndFrameworks.description: JavaScript has a vast selection of libraries and frameworks that simplify web application development and improve the maintainability and scalability of code.

react.title: React
react.description: Developed by Facebook, React is a library for building user interfaces with a focus on reusable components. It uses JSX, a syntax that combines JavaScript with HTML, making it easier to create interactive components.

angular.title: Angular
angular.description: Maintained by Google, Angular is a comprehensive framework that provides robust tools for developing complex front-end applications, including a dependency injection system, an integrated router, and a testing suite.

vue.title: Vue.js
vue.description: Vue is known for its simplicity and progressive architecture, allowing developers to opt into parts of the framework as needed. It combines a reactive API with a composable component system.

developmentEnvironments.title: Development Environments
developmentEnvironments.description: JavaScript has evolved beyond browsers thanks to environments like Node.js and Deno, which allow JavaScript to run on servers or in other computing contexts.

nodeJs.title: Node.js
nodeJs.description: Allows server-side application development using JavaScript. Node.js uses a non-blocking, event-driven model, making it efficient for real-time applications handling large data volumes.

deno.title: Deno

communitiesAndBlogs.title: Communities and Blogs
communitiesAndBlogs.description: Participating in communities and following blogs and online resources can be crucial for continuous learning and staying updated on the latest trends and best practices in JavaScript.

stackOverflow.title: Stack Overflow
stackOverflow.description: A vast community where developers can ask questions and share answers. It is an invaluable resource for solving specific programming problems.

todo_app_short_description: TaskTrack showcases streamlined task management through a minimalist MVP designed with modern web technologies. Perfect for demonstrating clean coding practices, responsive design and more.

introduction.subtitulo: Simplified task management through a minimalist MVP designed with modern web technologies. Perfect for demonstrating clean coding practices, responsive design, and more.

database_connection.title: 1.- Database Connection with Neon Tech
database_connection.description: The first step in developing the application was establishing a robust and efficient connection to the database using Neon Tech. Neon Tech provides modern, scalable database solutions, which allowed for effective handling of task and user data. The initial configuration included defining the necessary environment variables and integrating with Prisma to facilitate database operations.

crud_operations.title: 2.- CRUD Operations Implementation
crud_operations.description: Once the database connection was established, we proceeded to develop the CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) operations. These operations are fundamental for managing tasks within the application. API endpoints were implemented to interact with the database, ensuring the server could correctly handle requests to create, read, update, and delete tasks.

nextauth_integration.title: 3.- Integration of NextAuth for Authentication
nextauth_integration.description: To securely and efficiently handle user authentication, NextAuth was installed. NextAuth is a complete authentication library for Next.js applications that simplifies session and provider management. In this project, NextAuth was configured to use Google as the authentication provider, allowing users to log in using their Google accounts.

google_cloud_local.title: 4.- Google Cloud Configuration for Local Development
google_cloud_local.description: Google Cloud was configured to facilitate local development. This configuration included creating the necessary credentials for Google authentication and setting environment variables (GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID and GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET) so the application could securely communicate with Google services during development.

prisma_adapter_nextauth.title: 5.- Prisma Adapter for NextAuth
prisma_adapter_nextauth.description: To synchronize data models with the database, a Prisma adapter was connected to NextAuth. Prisma is an ORM (Object-Relational Mapping) that simplifies database interaction through typed models. The Prisma adapter allows NextAuth to manage accounts, sessions, and users directly in the database, ensuring a smooth and efficient integration.

api_development.title: 6.- API Development
api_development.description: With authentication and CRUD operations in place, the application's API was developed. The API handles frontend requests, interacts with the database via Prisma, and manages user sessions through NextAuth. Specific endpoints were implemented to handle retrieving, creating, updating, and deleting tasks, ensuring each operation was secured and properly validated.

app_styling.title: 7.- Application Styling
app_styling.description: Parallel to API development, light styling was applied to the application to enhance the user experience. Using CSS and React, intuitive and responsive visual components were designed, enabling smooth interaction with the application. The user interface focused on simplicity and functionality, ensuring users could efficiently manage their tasks.

auth_structure_nextauth.title: 8.- Authentication Structure with NextAuth
auth_structure_nextauth.description: Authentication configuration and management in Next.js using NextAuth with Google as the provider and Prisma as the database adapter.

authOptions.description: Configures NextAuth options, including the Google provider, Prisma adapter, and session strategies.

authHandler.description: authHandler.ts file: Exports authentication handlers for GET and POST routes, allowing NextAuth to manage authentication requests.

session_management_protection.title: 9.- Session Management and Route Protection
session_management_protection.description: Mechanisms were implemented to manage user sessions and protect routes that require authentication. Using the useSession hook from NextAuth on the frontend, the existence of an active session was verified before allowing access to certain parts of the application, such as the task dashboard.

frontend_components.title: 10.- Frontend Components Development
frontend_components.description: Several key frontend components were developed for the application's functionality.

SessionWrapper.description: SessionWrapper: Provides session context to all child components, allowing any component to access user session information.

DashboardPage.description: DashboardPage: The main page for authenticated users, displaying a personalized greeting, the user's profile picture, a form to create new tasks, and a list of existing tasks.

task_operations_api.title: 11.- Task Operations Handling in the API
task_operations_api.description: Functions were developed to handle task deletion and updating through the API.

deleteTask.description: Deletes a task by verifying the task ID validity. If valid, it removes it from the database and properly handles errors.

updateTask.description: Updates a task after validating the task ID and provided data. Handles errors and ensures appropriate response.

prisma_models_definition.title: 12.- Models Definition with Prisma
prisma_models_definition.description: Data models were defined using Prisma, which facilitated interaction with the database and ensured data integrity.

Task.description: Represents a task with fields for ID, title, completion status, and an optional relation to the user who created it.
Task.code:
model Task {
  id         Int      @id @default(autoincrement())
  title      String
  completed  Boolean  @default(false)
  user       User?    @relation(fields: [userId], references: [id])
  userId     String?
}

User.description: Represents a user with fields for ID, name, email, image, and relationships to tasks, accounts, and sessions.
User.code:
model User {
  id            String   @id @default(cuid())
  name          String?
  email         String?  @unique
  emailVerified DateTime?
  image         String?
  tasks         Task[]
  accounts      Account[]
  sessions      Session[]
}

prisma_configuration_client.title: 13.- Prisma Configuration and Client
prisma_configuration_client.description: Prisma was configured with an automatically generated client that facilitates interactions with the database. The configuration includes the database provider (PostgreSQL) and the connection URL, which is obtained from environment variables.

client.description: Generates the Prisma client using the 'prisma-client-js' provider.

datasource.description: Defines the data source, configuring PostgreSQL as the provider and the connection URL from environment variables.

frontend_session_management.title: 14.- Frontend Session Management
frontend_session_management.description: A session provider was implemented on the frontend using NextAuth's SessionProvider. This ensures that all child components have access to session information, allowing consistent authentication state management across the application.

session_provider.description: Provides session context to all child components through NextAuth's SessionProvider.

ui_ux.title: 15.- User Interface and Experience
ui_ux.description: The user interface was designed with simplicity and efficiency in mind. Upon logging in, the user is greeted with a personalized welcome and profile picture. A form is provided to create new tasks, along with a dynamic list displaying existing tasks. The application is responsive, ensuring an optimal experience across devices.

error_handling_validation.title: 16.- Error Handling and Validation
error_handling_validation.description: Robust mechanisms were implemented to handle errors and validate data on both the frontend and backend. Validations ensure that user-entered data is correct and complete before being processed. Additionally, database operation errors are handled appropriately, providing clear feedback to the user in case of failures. You can find more details in the repository!

deployment_testing.title: 17.- Deployment and Final Testing
deployment_testing.description: Finally, thorough testing was conducted to ensure all functionalities operated correctly. Frontend-backend interactions, session management, and data integrity in the database were verified. After confirming the application's stability, the final deployment was carried out, making it ready for user access.

technologies.title: 18.- Technologies
technologies.description: List of technologies used in the project, along with their description and specific use.

Next.js.description: Next.js is a React framework that allows for the generation of static websites and server-rendered web applications.
Next.js.usage: Used to structure the application, manage routing, handle API routes, and facilitate both server-side and client-side rendering.

React.js.description: React is a JavaScript library for building interactive and reusable user interfaces.
React.js.usage: Employed to develop user interface components, such as new task forms, task lists, and navigation elements.

TypeScript.description: TypeScript is a typed superset of JavaScript that compiles to plain JavaScript, providing static typing and better development tools.
TypeScript.usage: Used to write more robust and maintainable code, improving early error detection and facilitating development with autocomplete and type checking.

NextAuth.js.description: NextAuth.js is a complete authentication solution for Next.js applications, supporting multiple authentication providers.
NextAuth.js.usage: Implemented to manage user authentication, allowing login via Google and secure session management.

Prisma ORM.description: Prisma is a modern Object-Relational Mapping (ORM) that facilitates interaction with databases through typed models.
Prisma ORM.usage: Used to define and manage data models (such as users and tasks), perform database migrations, and simplify CRUD operations.

Prisma Adapter for NextAuth.description: An adapter that integrates Prisma ORM with NextAuth.js, allowing user account and session management directly in the database.
Prisma Adapter for NextAuth.usage: Facilitated synchronization between NextAuth's authentication models and the database, ensuring efficient user and session management.

Neon Tech (Neon).description: Neon is a modern serverless database platform offering scalable, managed PostgreSQL databases.
Neon Tech (Neon).usage: Used to host the PostgreSQL database, providing a scalable, high-performance solution for storing user and task data.

PostgreSQL.description: PostgreSQL is an open-source relational database management system known for its robustness and support for advanced features.
PostgreSQL.usage: Served as the main database to store information on users, tasks, and sessions, managed through Neon and Prisma.

Google Cloud.description: Google Cloud is a suite of cloud computing services offering infrastructure, platforms, and development tools.
Google Cloud.usage: Configured to manage Google authentication credentials, allowing users to log in via their Google accounts.

Tailwind CSS.description: Tailwind CSS is a utility-first CSS framework that allows for fast and consistent user interface design through pre-defined classes.
Tailwind CSS.usage: Used to style application components, providing a clean, responsive appearance without the need to write custom CSS from scratch.

Next.js API Routes.description: Next.js API routes allow for the creation of serverless API endpoints directly within a Next.js application.
Next.js API Routes.usage: Used to implement CRUD operations (Create, Read, Update, Delete) for tasks, handling backend logic and database interaction.

Next.js Image Component.description: The Next.js next/image component automatically optimizes images, improving image loading performance.
Next.js Image Component.usage: Used to display user profile photos in an optimized and responsive manner.

Environment Variables.description: Environment variables allow for the secure management of sensitive and environment-specific configurations.
Environment Variables.usage: Employed to store sensitive credentials like GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID, GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET, and DATABASE_URL, ensuring they are not exposed in the source code.

Prisma Client.description: Prisma Client is an automatically generated library that enables database interaction using a query-builder-like API.
Prisma Client.usage: Facilitated database operations from the backend, allowing for easy, typed creation, reading, updating, and deletion of records.

GitHub.description: GitHub is a Git repository hosting platform that facilitates collaboration and version control.
GitHub.usage: Used to manage the project's source code, maintain a change history through commits, and collaborate on development.

Vercel.description: Vercel is a deployment platform optimized for Next.js applications, offering serverless hosting and CDN.
Vercel.usage: Commonly used to deploy Next.js applications on Vercel due to its native integration and optimization for this framework.

Git (Version Control).description: Git is a distributed version control system that allows tracking changes in source code and collaborating with other developers.
Git (Version Control).usage: Essential for managing development history, branching for new features, and maintaining an organized workflow.

Node.js.description: Node.js is a JavaScript runtime environment for server-side execution.
Node.js.usage: Fundamental for running the application's backend, handling API routes, and managing dependencies via npm or yarn.

npm or Yarn.description: Package managers for JavaScript that allow for the installation and management of project dependencies.
npm or Yarn.usage: Used to install and manage required dependencies such as Next.js, React, Prisma, NextAuth.js, among others.

conclusion.title: Conclusion
conclusion.description: The development of the todo-app involved a combination of modern technologies and tools that facilitated the creation of a robust, scalable, and maintainable application. From efficient database management with Prisma and Neon Tech, to secure authentication with NextAuth.js and Google Cloud, each technology played a crucial role. Additionally, the use of Next.js and React ensured a smooth and responsive user experience, while Tailwind CSS enabled quick and consistent styling of interface components.

card.description: If you're intrigued by how this application was built, or simply want to dive into the code, you're just a click away! Exploring the repository, you can see every line that brings this small task app to life and learn about the technical details behind its functionality.

desafio.titulo: Challenge: Identifying Consistent Patterns in OCR Text
desafio.descripcion: When working with text extracted from receipt images using OCR (Optical Character Recognition), I encountered several obstacles:

obstaculos.descripcion: OCR can introduce errors due to image quality, font variations, and other factors.
Receipts may have different formats, making it difficult to locate specific information.
Simple methods to identify patterns resulted in an increasing margin of error.

metodos.enfoque: Search for simple patterns, such as two specific characters in a row.
metodos.problema: Generated many false positives due to the varied nature of OCR text.

metodos.enfoque: Divide the text into table-like structures to isolate information.
metodos.problema: The lack of consistency in text format made this method difficult, increasing the margin of error.

solucion.titulo: Solution: Developing an Effective Regular Expression
solucion.descripcion: To overcome these challenges, I needed a way to reliably identify amounts in Mexican pesos within the extracted text. This led to the creation of the regular expression:

analisis_detallado.significado: Escapes the $ character to literally search for the peso sign.
analisis_detallado.funcion: Ensures that the search starts where the peso sign appears, a key identifier for amounts.

analisis_detallado.significado: Defines a capture group to extract the numeric value of the amount.
analisis_detallado.funcion: Allows isolating the number for further processing.
Captures the hundreds, tens, and units of the amount, covering amounts from $0 to $999.

analisis_detallado.significado: A non-capturing group that searches for zero or more repetitions of a comma followed by three digits.
detalle: ?: indicates that the group is non-capturing.
,\d{3} searches for a comma followed by exactly three digits.
* allows this pattern to appear zero or more times.
analisis_detallado.funcion: Captures thousand separators, allowing recognition of amounts like $1,000, $10,000, $100,000, etc.

analisis_detallado.significado: Searches for a dot followed by exactly two digits.
analisis_detallado.funcion: Captures the cents, ensuring that the amount has two decimals as standard in currencies.

razones_por_que_funciona.descripcion: By searching for the peso sign followed by a specific numeric pattern, it reduces the likelihood of false positives.
Handles amounts with and without thousand separators, adapting to different number formats.
By requiring two decimals after the dot, it ensures that valid monetary amounts are captured.

proceso_de_desarrollo.titulo: Development Process and Logic Behind the Solution

descripcion: The peso sign $ is a distinctive character that precedes monetary amounts on receipts.
Using it as a starting point helps anchor the search in the correct place.
Amounts can vary in length and format, so I needed an expression that:
Accepted small and large amounts: From $1.00 to $1,000,000.00.
Handled thousand separators: Commas that separate groups of three digits.
Included cents: Two digits after the decimal point.
By focusing on specific numeric patterns, the regular expression is more resistant to common OCR errors, such as confusing letters with numbers.
However, it's important to recognize that some errors might escape, so it's useful to combine this method with additional validations.

pasos_clave.descripcion: I split the text into lines to analyze each one individually.
I search in each line for an amount that matches the defined pattern.

descripcion: Cost (cost): Captured by the group in the regular expression.
- I split the line into parts around the peso sign.
- I look for the last number before the peso sign, assuming it represents the consumption.
- I use another regular expression to capture the billing period.

pasos_clave.descripcion: If all data is present, I add it to a results array for further processing.

desafios.problema: Receipts may present amounts and consumptions in different positions or formats.
desafios.solucion: Design a flexible regular expression and analysis logic that can adapt to different line structures.

desafios.problema: Misrecognized characters can affect the accuracy of the analysis.
desafios.solucion: Implement additional validations and, if necessary, image preprocessing to improve OCR quality.

desafios.problema: Not all lines will contain all the necessary information.
desafios.solucion: Include checks and handle cases where certain data is not available, preventing the program from failing.

impacto_y_valor.titulo: Impact and Added Value of This Solution

puntos.descripcion: By extracting data more reliably, the accuracy of the annual consumption calculation is improved, and thus, the quality of financial projections offered to the user.
Users don't have to manually enter their consumption, which facilitates the process and reduces the possibility of human errors.
The solution can be adapted to recognize other patterns or extract additional information if necessary.

keyConcepts.abstractData: The DataProvider allows React Admin to interact with any RESTful API without worrying about implementation details.
keyConcepts.crudOperations: It must implement methods to handle basic operations: getList, getOne, create, update, delete, getMany, getManyReference, updateMany, and deleteMany.
keyConcepts.responseStandardization: Each method must return data in a format that React Admin can understand and process.

implementationDetails.summary: Below is a detailed summary of how each DataProvider method was implemented, highlighting key aspects and design decisions made.

implementation.apiUrl: An apiUrl constant pointing to the API base URL was defined, allowing flexibility to switch between environments (development, production).
implementation.httpClient: React Admin's fetchUtils.fetchJson was used as the HTTP client, facilitating requests and automatically handling necessary headers.

2.title: getList Method
2.purpose: Retrieve a list of records from a specific resource, with support for pagination, filtering, and sorting.

implementation.Step 1: Pagination (page, perPage), sorting (field, order), and filtering (filter) parameters were extracted from params.
implementation.Step 2: A query was built with these parameters using query-string to serialize the object to a query string.
implementation.Step 3: The response was handled to extract the data and the total number of records, using the content-range header.

considerations.Error Handling: The content-range header was checked to ensure the server provides the necessary information.
considerations.Response Format: An object was returned with data and total properties, where data is an array of records and total is the total number of available records.

3.title: getOne Method
3.purpose: Retrieve a single record based on its ID.

implementation.Step 1: The URL was built using the resource and params.id.
implementation.Step 2: A GET request was made, and the data obtained was returned.

considerations.efficiency: This method is essential for viewing record details without overloading the API.

4.title: create Method
4.purpose: Create a new record on the server.

implementation.Step 1: A POST request was made to the corresponding resource, sending params.data in the request body.
implementation.Step 2: Necessary headers were included, such as Content-Type: application/json.
implementation.Step 3: The response was handled to include the ID generated by the server in the returned data object.

considerations.Data Validation: Before sending the data, it is important to ensure it meets the server's requirements.
considerations.Activity Logging: A console.log was included to verify the data sent during development.

implementation.Step 1: The URL was built including params.id.
implementation.Step 2: A PUT request was made with the updated data in params.data.
implementation.Step 3: The updated data was returned to the client.

considerations.idempotency: Using PUT ensures the operation is idempotent, replacing the existing record with the new data.

implementation.step 1: A DELETE request was made to the resource URL with params.id.
implementation.step 2: The response was handled to confirm the record was deleted.

considerations.deletionConfirmation: It is good practice to handle possible errors if the record does not exist or cannot be deleted.

7.title: getMany Method
7.purpose: Retrieve multiple records based on an array of IDs.

implementation.step 1: A query was built by filtering by ID using params.ids.
implementation.step 2: A GET request was made, and the corresponding records were returned.

considerations.efficiency: Useful for retrieving references or relationships between records without making multiple individual requests.

8.title: getManyReference Method
8.purpose: Retrieve records that are related to another specific record.

implementation.step 1: Similar to getList, but with an additional filter based on params.target and params.id.

considerations.Data Relationships: Facilitates viewing and managing related data, such as comments on a post.

9.title: updateMany and deleteMany Methods
9.purpose: Update or delete multiple records at once.

implementation.step 1: Implemented as asynchronous functions that return a resolved promise with an empty array.
implementation.note: This is a dummy implementation to comply with the interface and can be improved to support these operations according to backend capabilities.

considerations.futureImprovements: Depending on needs, these operations can be implemented to optimize performance when handling data batches.

implementation.composition: All methods were imported and included in a dataProvider object that meets the interface expected by React Admin.
implementation.exportation: The dataProvider was exported to be used in the React Admin configuration.
implementation.flexibility: This modularity allows each method to be maintained and updated independently.

highlightedAspectsAndSkills.Modularity And Reuse: Each CRUD operation was implemented in separate modules, facilitating code maintainability and scalability.

portfolioData.title: Request Management and Security in Web Applications
portfolioData.introduction2: In this project, I implemented key functionalities to improve the security and efficiency of our web application using Next.js. Two main components I developed are determining the user's IP address and controlling the number of requests a user can make within a certain time period. Below, I detail how these components contribute to the application's performance and security, accompanied by code examples demonstrating their implementation.

sections.title: User IP Address Identification
sections.description: To personalize and secure our users' experience, it is essential to know where they are connecting from. I developed a function that detects the client's IP address making each request to our server. This information is essential for several reasons:

reasons.title: Security
reasons.description: By knowing the IP, we can identify and prevent malicious activities, such as unauthorized access attempts.

reasons.title: Personalization
reasons.description: Allows adapting content and functionalities based on the user's geographical location.

reasons.title: Traffic Analysis
reasons.description: Helps better understand user behavior and optimize application performance.

importations.description: Specific request type for Next.js applications.
Function from the request-ip library that attempts to extract the client's IP from the request.

function.name: getClientIpWrapper
function.purpose: Obtain the IP address of the client making the request.

process.step1: Attempt to Obtain IP with request-ip: Tries to get the client's IP using getClientIp(req). If an error occurs, it is caught and logged to the console.
process.step2: Fallback in Case of Error or Missing IP: If clientIp is not obtained via request-ip, the function attempts to manually extract it from the request headers (x-forwarded-for or remote-addr). If the IP still cannot be determined, the local IP '127.0.0.1' is assigned as the default value.
process.step3: Logging and Returning the IP: The obtained IP is logged to the console for debugging purposes and returned to the caller.

sections.title: Request Rate Limiting
sections.description: To protect our application from overloads and abuses, I implemented a request rate limiting system. This system regulates how many times a user can interact with our application within specific time intervals, such as per minute, per hour, or per day. The advantages of this implementation include:

advantages.title: Attack Prevention
advantages.description: Prevents malicious users from sending a large number of requests in a short time, which could overwhelm the server and affect all users.

advantages.title: Resource Optimization
advantages.description: Ensures that server resources are used efficiently, guaranteeing consistent performance for all users.

advantages.title: Improved User Experience
advantages.description: By preventing overloads, legitimate users enjoy a smooth and uninterrupted experience.

function.name: rateLimit
function.purpose: Create a middleware that limits the number of requests an IP can make within a specific time window.

parameters.name: windowMs
parameters.description: Duration of the time window in milliseconds.

parameters.name: max
parameters.description: Maximum number of requests allowed within the time window.

parameters.name: message
parameters.description: Error message returned when the limit is exceeded.

process.step1: Request Storage (hits): Uses a Map to track the timestamps of requests made by each IP.

substeps.obtencionDeLaIP: Uses getClientIpWrapper to determine the client's IP.
substeps.actualizacionDeTimestamps: Filters the timestamps that are still within the current time window (windowMs).
substeps.verificacionDeLimites: If the number of requests within the window exceeds max, it logs to the console and returns an object with status 429 (Too Many Requests) and the corresponding message. If the limit is not exceeded, it adds the current timestamp to the records and allows the next function (next) to proceed, returning status 200 (OK).

minuteLimiter.description: Allows a maximum of 2 requests per minute.

hourlyLimiter.description: Allows a maximum of 5 requests per hour.

dailyLimiter.description: Allows a maximum of 10 requests per day.

portfolioData.impact:
The incorporation of these functionalities has significantly strengthened the security and efficiency of our web application. By identifying users' IP addresses and controlling the frequency of their requests, we have achieved:

- Protecting the application against unauthorized access and denial-of-service attacks.
- Ensuring optimal performance even under high traffic loads, guaranteeing a reliable and satisfying user experience.
- Facilitating analysis and personalization, allowing informed decisions based on user behavior and location.

These implementations demonstrate my ability to address security and performance challenges in modern web applications, ensuring that solutions are not only effective but also scalable and sustainable in the long term.
portfolioData.finalComment:
This approach to user identification and request management reflects a commitment to security, efficiency, and user experience, which are fundamental aspects in developing robust and reliable web applications.

This summary, accompanied by code examples, provides a clear view of the technical solutions implemented to enhance the security and performance of the web application. By including code snippets, visitors to your portfolio can appreciate not only the final outcome but also the technical implementation behind each functionality.

autobiography.title: I'm not good at talking about myself, but here we go... anything for a job and learn.
content: My name is Tomas Arvedson, I am half Colombian and half Swedish, but more Mexican than the cactus itself.

I was born and raised in Bogotá, Colombia, where I lived until I was 11. I currently live in Mexico, a country known for its freedom, geographic beauty, and culinary culture, where I moved due to my father's career in mining.

autobiography.title: A new culture? I don't think so
content: When I arrived in Mexico, I integrated quickly, except in one aspect: spicy food.
It took me some time to get used to it, but after a few tries, my friends accepted me as I mastered the most intense levels of spice.

autobiography.title: Education? Rebellion
content: I completed high school and began a career in engineering in mining and construction, where I developed my technical skills.

However, I took a critical stance towards the educational system. I believed knowledge should be accessible and free from financial constraints, and I rebelled against what I saw as a capitalization on errors.

autobiography.title: The First World
content: Towards the end of my studies, I decided to withdraw to seek real motivation in my life.

I moved to England, where I worked in a warehouse until the pandemic forced me to reconsider my perspective on the world and human purpose. It was there that I began studying geopolitics, history, wars, and adversities that humanity has faced—not as naturally as we believe, but rather to maintain the structure of power and benefits for the few in the apparent interest of all.

autobiography.title: Reality Check
content: When I left England due to excessive lockdowns, I moved to Dallas, Texas, to train in renewable energy and door-to-door sales.
It was a very demanding job, with temperatures reaching 113°F (45°C), but gratifying due to the resilience I developed day by day.

autobiography.title: No Empty Spaces
content: I returned to Mexico to be close to my family because nothing compares to seeing what's most important to me day after day.
I thought that beyond my future, it was my present that really mattered—to be close to the people who, at some point, will no longer be there. People who gave me love and life.

autobiography.title: My Career, The Jack of All Trades
content: Since I set my career aside due to being a frustrated musician and a critic of the system with a fear of capitalist failure, I had to start from scratch several times.

I attempted the nearly impossible path of trading, developing a kind of hyper-aware gambling addiction to risk. For two years of day trading, I managed to multiply my initial capital almost tenfold; however, my ambition was more consistent than a solid statistical method, and my mind and principles changed drastically. I sacrificed two years of my life and quite a few salaries, only to dissolve them in a matter of weeks. I didn’t want to see a trading account again for years. The next time I trade, it won’t be me personally; it will be a script to avoid the mistakes a human could make.

The good thing about following that path is that I learned a lot about economics, finance, geoeconomics, banking systems, hard money, fiduciary systems, commodities, markets and their laws, and much more!

Shortly after, realizing that energy is the core of the value humans perceive as effort (J), I went to learn about photovoltaic systems and how to sell them. If there is something difficult in this life, it's door-to-door sales. I never imagined I would become an expert in communication along the way. After knocking on over 15,000 doors, I could read certain traits that seemed universal in humans. After being locked in a warehouse all day, in a 5x5 room doing trading all night with the volatility of the lockdown, I was grateful to have spoken to so many people.

Then I returned to Mexico to start a business close to my family, and I started programming because I thought it was too easy :) Many of my close friends had studied computer systems or mechatronics, so they were my guides and provided all the knowledge on a silver platter. I am very grateful to them, especially to Axel, a great teacher.

99% of what you see was self-taught. Nobody ever gave me a problem to solve or even a question to answer; my mind was the problem, and the questions came from there—from errors in the console, from hunger, and from concern. I keep going, I keep learning, I don't stop.
Algorithm problems, pseudocode, and JS—thinking, thinking, and thinking. Funny how naturally it came to me. Then HTML, easy; CSS, not so much.

React was the cherry on top. Intermittently, I tried NoSQL before SQL. It was challenging, but I learned the hard way. I also managed to grasp Django, Ruby on Rails, and Laravel. A friend who is an expert in data, noticing my rapid progress, invited me to one of his projects, where I even got to work with Flask for Python.
At this moment, I have about 12 effective months programming. I’ve spoken to several graduates in computer science, and it seems as though I went to school with aliens (:

I want to reach the next level of learning; I want to work in large teams, to learn from those who know, to surround myself with real experts and prove to myself through them that I am good at this. I may not have the best resume, but every line of this project is dedicated to proving I can be of service to you.

I am also the co-founder of a solar energy company in Mexico. However, to fulfill the goal of allowing all Mexicans to buy a piece of a solar park, rather than foreign companies with their financing and interest over the Mexican people, I have to give them a great application.
I am always willing to make sacrifices. The time has come, and a new chapter in my life begins.

autobiography.title: Current Focus
content: I am focused on learning; that's the only way to reach the next step. Dreams may exist, but to achieve them, we must understand what the universe is made of.
I am focused on becoming an expert developer, full-stack front and back.
When I have a team under my guidance, I will have all the knowledge and will be able to take the reins of what’s to come: an application for my solar company.
